intro: Isopogon longifolius, commonly known as the long-leaved banksia, is a species of flowering plant in the family Proteaceae. It is native to the south-western region of Western Australia, where it grows in heathlands and sandy soils. The plant is characterized by its long, narrow leaves and its distinctive cylindrical flower spike. It produces yellow to orange flowers that bloom in spring, attracting nectar-feeding birds and insects. Isopogon longifolius is often used in native gardens due to its ornamental value and ecological benefits.
